bibl.title: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wickliffe Rose, February 24, 1923

div1.p: Carter and her father hold Rose's opinion in high esteem, and she thanks Rose for his praise of Henry Rose Carter's work on the History of Yellow Fever and of her poetry.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Wickliffe Rose, February 24, 1923

opener.dateline:
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
February 24, 1923.

div1.p:
As a rule following “flu,” one feels little enthusiasm--
simply doggedly holds on to principles and objectives and hopes
for “better days”--but your letter of February 17th. has impart-
ed an inward glow which has entirely obliterated the ill effects
of that disease. Indeed, I doubt if Dr. Flexner will ever evolve
so good an antidote therefor!

Many years ago, after an interview with you in New York,
I recollect Father saying: “Laura, I never met a man with a
clearer: more constructive or more illuminating mind than Dr.
Rose. Give him the data on any subject--familiar or otherwise--
and he will at once grasp their relative importance: coordinate
them and make the right deductions. A remarkable mind!” Such
a letter as you wrote then, is in the nature of an accolade--
something to be treasured in the family archives.

Your appreciation of Father's work on the History of Yellow
Fever--which I agree with you no one else could do so well--is a
source of great gratification to us both.

For myself, I am happy that I can be of service and deeply
appreciate what you said in this connection. Indeed, after work-
ing together so long, I expect Father would not find it easy to
work so expeditiously with anyone else. You see, when he gets in-
terested he's just as apt to work twelve hours as eight, and even
after that to take up a bit of old Spanish or Latin or Nahautl for
“light reading” in connection with the early history of yellow
fever. For any and all of this I, being on the spot, am always
available and as interested as is he. I know you do not wish Father
Father
-2-
to feel pressed about finishing the book--you have been beautiful-
ly thoughtful and considerate about every aspect of the case--but
when he starts he gathers so much momentum its hard for him to stop.

What you said of my verses made me very happy and it was
just like you to tell me to save time for my beloved personal
writing, but this is not possible until the work with Father is
finished. It is not even a question of “relativity” since the
values of the two pieces of work are not comparable.

With very best remembrances, in which Father joins, and
again thanking you for your much valued letter,
